values.alignmentText: North Korea's state-controlled economy assigns coders to government bureaus; no private market or remote work—no viable .NET path for Trey.
KP 2D environmental artist pay isn’t benchmarked. Compensation trails global norms and is tightly regulated, limiting relocation appeal for your family.
North Korea (KP) offers virtually no local 2D environmental artist continuing education. Any upskilling would rely on scarce external or remote resources.
North Korea offers virtually no local 2D environmental artist programs (Pyongyang). Curricula are scarce; study abroad/online options unavailable.
North Korea: 2D environmental artist hiring is very slow; local pipelines are shallow, with reliance on remote or imported talent extending timelines.
North Korea has limited English among 2D environmental artists; English-speaking talent is rare. Expect translation and local-language collaboration.
North Korea's restricted internet and state studios mean remote 2D environmental art roles aren't feasible. Onsite presence is expected.
North Korea has essentially no local 2D environmental artist professionals. Global hiring or relocation would be impractical.
3D animator pay in North Korea is far below global norms due to a centralized economy. Relocation would require substantial supplements and benefits.
In North Korea, formal 3D animation continuing education is virtually non-existent; learning hinges on scarce informal peer sessions.
In Pyongyang, North Korea, 3D animation education is virtually non-existent. Graduates would need to study abroad or online.
In North Korea, 3D animator roles are rarely filled locally; pipelines are shallow. Remote or imported talent is usually required with long timelines.
North Korea: 3D animation talent is largely Korean; English usage is limited; translation/onboarding and bilingual collaboration are common.
North Korea's strict internet controls make remote 3D animator roles rare. On-site studios are more common, with limited or no remote options.
KP has a very thin 3D animator pool; most work is in state studios, making external relocation or remote hires likely necessary.
North Korea offers negligible 3D artist pay; virtually no remote work or benefits; relocation financially untenable.
North Korea has virtually no local 3D character artist courses; learning would rely on scarce remote options and very limited internet access.
North Korea lacks a dedicated 3D character art curriculum; students must study online or abroad, with scarce local programs.
KP: Local 3D character artist hires are effectively impossible; remote/global access is constrained; expect very long or blocked hiring.
North Korea's 3D art scene has minimal English; expect Korean-language work with translators; onboarding and collaboration slow.
In North Korea, remote 3D character work is largely non-existent; onsite roles dominate, with rare exceptions, misaligned with this family's remote plans.
In Pyongyang, North Korea, there are effectively no in-market 3D character artists; relocation or remote hires from abroad would be needed.
North Korea has virtually no game-focused accelerators or incubators; access to external startup programs is essentially non-existent.
In Pyongyang, DPRK, air quality is poor with PM2.5 spikes. Seal windows and use high-grade purifiers.
In North Korea (KP), anchor employers are virtually nonexistent; only state studios exist, with no major private studios.
In North Korea (DPRK), atheism is state doctrine. Expressing nonbelief can be treated as dissent and threaten safety.
North Korea (KP) shows near-total authoritarian control. Civil liberties are dismantled for residents.
In KP, sanctions and rationed commerce mean foreigners can't rely on cards; daily transactions would be nearly impossible for us.
Beaches in North Korea are largely inaccessible to foreign families due to government restrictions; beach life is impractical.
In North Korea, public boardgaming is virtually nonexistent; Trey and the kids would rely on private, imported games for home play.
In DPRK, body norms are state-driven; fitness talk is rare and conformity pressures shape social life, not health.
In North Korea, the state-led economy is fragile; job options are limited and layoffs can spike during crises.
In North Korea (KP), cancer incidence is elevated due to environmental and policy gaps; screening and care access are strained.
North Korea (KP) prisons and camps rely on forced labor with harsh conditions and minimal oversight. Human rights concerns are severe.
Childcare in North Korea (KP) is scarce and tightly state-controlled; reliable private options are nearly nonexistent for families.
North Korea's cities offer virtually no child-friendly amenities; tight controls are common. Pervasive surveillance makes outings stressful.
North Korea's state childcare offers limited autonomy and options; affordable, reliable care is scarce.
In Pyongyang, North Korea, visa families have virtually no access to public childcare subsidies; private care is scarce and costly.
In North Korea, hobby scenes are tightly controlled. Independent geeky groups are scarce, limiting social hobbies.
In North Korea (KP), local professional events are scarce; expect minimal community activity and reliance on state channels or restricted online forums.
In KP, public health messaging is state-led and access to care is uneven; families must actively maintain routines and seek reliable clinics.
North Korea (KP): community living options for families are effectively non-existent. State housing dominates with limited family-friendly programs.
North Korea: community manager pay is unreliable with scarce benefits; local offers trail global benchmarks due to isolation.
North Korea offers minimal local training for community managers; access to online courses is restricted, so learning is largely informal or unavailable.
In North Korea (Pyongyang), no local community manager programs exist; candidates would need study abroad or online options.
In North Korea (KP), local Community Manager hiring is effectively non-existent. Global searches or remote or imported talent would be required.
In KP (North Korea), English use is rare for CM roles; Korean with interpreters is standard—consider bilingual, remote-capable candidates.
North Korea (KP) has virtually no remote CM roles; expect full onsite work with rare exceptions, conflicting with the family's remote-friendly goals.
KP has no identifiable local community manager professionals; market effectively absent due to strict controls and limited connectivity.
North Korea (KP) communities are cold toward outsiders; suspicion and limited openness would complicate the family's newcomer integration.
In North Korea (KP), reliable studio compensation data is scarce; roles are rare, remote opportunities unlikely.
KP startup pay is unreliable; private sector scarce and remote US packages unlikely, with illiquid equity, not aligned with this family's needs.
North Korea's compliance regime is punitive and opaque; minor missteps can lead to detention or deportation for expats. Recourse is limited.
North Korea offers virtually no local continuing education for expats; expect self-study or scarce external programs, often inaccessible.
North Korea's contractor pool is effectively nonexistent. Sanctions and limited internet hinder reliable onboarding for freelancers.
North Korea enforces draconian drug laws and heavy policing; even minor infractions risk harsh penalties.
KP imposes extreme constraints (sanctions, limited internet/cloud access); operating costs and compliance render startups prohibitively expensive.
North Korea's cost of living is distorted by scarcity and sanctions; even low prices are offset by shortages, making budgets fragile.
In North Korea, coworking and startup labs are virtually nonexistent; indie game dev infra is unavailable, so teams must work remotely.
Demand far outstrips supply in North Korea; foreign tech roles are effectively unavailable, pushing relocation or alternative hubs.
North Korea (KP) shows common depression with limited mental health care; plan for under-treatment and rely on family support and private coping.
North Korea enforces strict privacy norms and conformity, making deep bonds hard. For newcomers, meaningful friendships are rare, even with effort.
North Korea's D&I landscape offers virtually no inclusive protections; for your progressive US family, civil liberties and LGBTQ+ rights are severely restricted.
In North Korea (KP), drug enforcement is extreme; daily life is shadowed by fear of raids and police abuse.
North Korea (KP) does not recognize dual citizenship; U.S. protection would not apply to a US-KP dual national.
KC, MO offers roughly $150k-$350k in early grants (SBIR-like + state/private) for Trey’s game/soft startup.
In KP, early-stage game funding is virtually non-existent; no local investors or grants. Founders would need relocation or international capital.
North Korea's sanctions and shortages create severe economic distress; unreliable markets and scarce capital hinder our startup plans.
KP's rigid command economy blocks private enterprise and market freedom, hindering entrepreneurship and access to grants for families.
North Korea's policy regime is centralized and opaque, offering little predictability for creative ventures. Sanctions and regime changes keep risk high.
In DPRK, education is ideology-driven and underfunded; modern resources and bilingual options are scarce for our kids.
In North Korea, game-focused education is virtually non-existent; talent must study abroad or online.
In North Korea (DPRK), employer visa sponsorship is effectively unavailable; US families face extreme entry barriers and scarce work visa options.
In KP, engine communities are virtually nonexistent. Access to Unity/Unreal forums and collaboration is severely restricted.
North Korea (KP) environment is severely compromised: polluted air and few safe outdoor spaces hinder our family's outdoor time.
KP tax policy for foreigners is opaque; no transparent rate, unpredictable levies undermine budget and relocation viability for our family.
North Korea autumn is generally mild (roughly 12-20°C); plan for a few early cold snaps or windy days.
In North Korea, state dictates roles and limits family life; private, supportive family spaces are scarce.
North Korea (KP) limits foreign family visas; reunification is highly unlikely for a U.S. family amid strict controls and limited services.
In North Korea, family support is limited; parental benefits exist in theory but are overshadowed by surveillance and coercive controls.
North Korea's family policy is tightly state-controlled with limited support; non-traditional families face suppression and minimal aid.
In Pyongyang, North Korea, visa-holding families face near-total exclusion from state benefits; support is effectively unavailable for non-citizens.
In North Korea, fashion is tightly controlled and conservative; casual Western wear may draw scrutiny - plan modest, locally appropriate outfits.
North Korea (KP) enforces strict dress norms for women. Deviation risks harassment, so outfits should align with modest, state-influenced standards.
In North Korea, male dress is tightly regulated. Plan conservative, non-polarizing attire to avoid sanctions.
Femininity is tightly policed in the DPRK; women's autonomy is limited, with conformity expected in dress, behavior, and roles. This may constrain Sarah's autonomy.
North Korea (KP) enforces strict gun control; private ownership is virtually non-existent. Firearms are state-controlled, keeping exposure low.
Consent norms in North Korea are shaped by strict social controls. Nightlife is sparse and interactions are closely policed.
North Korea lacks a private founder/operator network; expect almost no mentorship circles or venture ecosystems for startup founders.
North Korea offers minimal fresh and international cuisine; outside Pyongyang, options are extremely limited.
In KP, neighbors are rarely welcoming to newcomers; social life is tightly controlled, leaving the family feeling isolated.
KC, USA offers $500k–$1.2M/year in game-dev grants from public/private sources; aligns with a founder-led plan.
In KP, local game dev studios are virtually non-existent; Trey would face few or no opportunities.
North Korea does not recognize gender diversity in law; documents are binary. Access to rights and services is limited, increasing risk for families.
In DPRK (KP), gender rights are tightly controlled; women face state restrictions and limited autonomy despite official rhetoric.
North Korea's traditional gender norms and state oversight shape roles; daily life remains conservative and tightly regulated.
In KP (North Korea), gender scripts are tightly regulated; progressive, inclusive flirting would face strong social scrutiny.
KP would severely restrict visa holders: restricted internet, exit controls, and limited mobility, untenable for a U.S. family with two kids.
North Korea (KP) faces rising droughts and floods; climate risks are high, so evacuation planning should be part of family planning.
North Korea has no practical startup visas; entry is tightly controlled and typically requires government approval. Relocation for US founders is highly infeasible.
KP's pervasive state control and surveillance curb self-expression; grooming is strictly regulated, making our lifestyle untenable.
KP: Group/multi-partner households face severe social and legal penalties; no institutional acceptance or protections.
Healthcare in North Korea is inconsistent; medicines and doctors are scarce. Major treatments often require overseas travel.
North Korea visa families face restricted hospital access; public hospitals are limited and reimbursements scarce, increasing out-of-pocket costs.
North Korea (KP): higher education for citizens hinges on loyalty/songbun; merit is often secondary and access is uneven; foreign access is severely restricted.
North Korea offers virtually no higher-ed access for visa holders; as a US-based family you'd face scarce programs and tight entry rules.
North Korea lacks established game studios; local hiring is effectively non-existent, leaving minimal chance to fill roles.
In North Korea, private startups are illegal; early-stage hiring is effectively non-existent, so remote or relocated talent would be required.
North Korea's housing is state-allocated; scarce, with unreliable heat/maintenance, making secure, family-friendly homes hard to find.
North Korea (KP) tax rules are opaque and centralized, with little digital tooling. Compliance feels arbitrary and risky for families.
In DPRK (KP), immigrants face open hostility and strict scrutiny; daily life for newcomers can feel unsafe.
North Korea (KP) treats white migrants with suspicion and legal limits; despite good faith, belonging remains hard and locals may keep distance.
North Korea’s public K-12 is universal but resource-poor and tightly controlled; families face limited materials and slower progress.
In DPRK, visa-holding foreign kids generally cannot enroll in public schools; private tutoring is the main option and remains tightly supervised.
In DPRK (KP), few English speakers; rely on interpreters, and study Korean to navigate services.
North Korea (KP): English use is limited; Korean fluency is key for studios and partnerships. Your plan to learn Korean aligns with local reality.
North Korea has scarce English resources. Startups must use Korean localization for hiring, compliance, and outreach (investor comms in Korean).
North Korea offers almost no local game IP/legal resources; founders must seek counsel outside the country.

In North Korea (KP), market research and playtesting are virtually unavailable. There are no local panels or labs accessible to a foreign family.
North Korea (KP) tightly controls Marxist discourse; dissent risks punishment. This clashes with the family's progressive, liberty-first values.
In DPRK, masculinity is tightly policed by the state; Trey's creativity and emotional expression risk sanction.
In KP, regional tensions and state security elevate mass-violence risk; stay vigilant at large gatherings and public venues.
In North Korea, independent meetups are banned; there are no safe spaces for open-source or parenting groups.
Wages in North Korea are symbolic under a state-planned system; most income comes from rationed goods and jobs with limited security.
North Korea's power outages and limited broadband undermine remote work and schooling; connectivity is intermittent outside major hubs like Pyongyang.
In North Korea (KP), non-monogamy is extremely risky under state norms; openness could jeopardize safety, housing, and employment.
In Pyongyang, openness can invite state backlash; guard family privacy and share concerns only with trusted, discreet contacts.
North Korea's mountains and coastlines can be striking. Travel permits and restricted access make family-friendly outdoor time hard to arrange.
North Korea (KP) faces floods and seasonal storms; evacuation and repair planning advised, though rebuilding varies by area.
Nature access in North Korea (KP) is restricted; hikes often require escorts or permits, limiting outdoor time for our family.
Nightlife in North Korea is tightly controlled and largely state-organized. For a family, authentic nightlife is minimal; independent music scenes are rare.
In North Korea (KP), curfews and surveillance limit evening life; casual nightlife is effectively gone for families.
In North Korea (KP), there are virtually no independent game dev meetups or studios. Trey would have minimal peer networks.
In North Korea (KP), there are no notable game studios; only state propaganda studios exist, providing no career mentorship for Trey.
Obesity rates in North Korea are generally low. This supports our family's health goals in KP, with active living and balanced nutrition.
Opportunities for Video Game Startup: In North Korea, private studios are largely prohibited; internet access is restricted and state control blocks indie developers.
North Korea's pace is structured and calm, generally slower than a typical US metro. This supports steady family routines with fewer rushed moments.
In KP, North Korea, state controls family life; diverse parenting is rare and deviation risks government scrutiny.
In DPRK (KP), foreign naturalization is effectively non-existent; permanent residency is not available for this family.
In North Korea, corruption is embedded; many services rely on informal channels and favors, shaping daily life and bureaucratic friction.
In DPRK (KP), personal boundaries are tightly managed. Expect formal etiquette and limited private space in public, with pervasive surveillance.
In Pyongyang, close contact is common in dense spaces; expect limited personal space and rely on formal cues until rapport is built.
Pyongyang, DPRK has cold winters and hot, humid summers; only short spring/autumn windows, so outdoor life is limited most of the year.
KP's Pyongyang autocracy with dynastic leadership; no meaningful political freedom and no real democratic norms.
In North Korea, polyamory is stigmatized and legally unsupported. Polyamorous families face social pressure and potential legal risk.
In North Korea, state early care covers all, but enrichment is limited. Ideology dominates and bilingual options are unlikely.
In KP, private education is unavailable to foreigners. Schools are state-run and ideological, limiting private options for this family.
North Korea (KP) has scarce fresh foods. Processed options are limited and often inconsistent.
North Korea (KP) PMM (Games) pay benchmarks are scarce; salaries are far below global norms with limited benefits, making relocation unlikely for this family.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Continuing Education Availability
values.alignmentText: North Korea offers little structured continuing education for games product marketing; expect informal peer sessions or self-study, with few local workshops.

values.key: Product Marketing Manager (Games): Education Pipeline Strength
values.alignmentText: Pyongyang, North Korea has no dedicated product marketing manager (games) pathway; curricula are scarce and cross-border study is tightly controlled.
North Korea (KP): PMM (Games) roles have no realistic local path; global hiring is unlikely due to strict controls and limited internet access.
English usage in NK is limited; expect translation/onboarding support and Korean language exposure; prioritize bilingual-capable teams if available.
Remote PMM (Games) roles in KP (North Korea) are scarce due to strict controls and limited connectivity. Remote options exist only case-by-case.
North Korea (KP) has effectively no in-market product marketing managers (games); private gaming sector is minimal and talent is effectively absent.
In North Korea (KP), progressive civil society is effectively nonexistent. Politics are state-controlled, offering little outlet for your values.
North Korea's culture is highly controlled; open talk about relationships invites state and community policing; privacy is essential.
In Pyongyang, North Korea, state propaganda saturates media and schooling; your family's pluralistic, media-diverse values clash with daily life here.
In North Korea (KP), state media dominates daily life; independent outlets are banned, making propaganda pervasive and discouraging diverse viewpoints.
Pyongyang's metro and buses reach few areas, and foreigners are restricted, leaving us with minimal usable transit.
KP offers essentially no local publisher access. Platform relationships must come from international channels outside Korea.
North Korea (KP) is hostile to affluent living; luxury services are scarce and bureaucracy high. A split-time approach or relocation may be needed.
North Korea (KP): lower-income families face crisis conditions; scarce healthcare, housing, and public support limit stability for a family with kids.
In DPRK (KP), middle-income families face severe scarcity and limited mobility. State controls strain budgets and wellbeing.

North Korea features rare crime but heavy state control and arbitrary detention; daily life and mobility depend on regime approval.
North Korea's centralized, ideology-driven schooling leaves few acceptable options for the boys. Private/international choices are unavailable.
KP coastal waters run 20-22 C in summer; shoulder months dip to 20 C, so swimming is feasible about half the year.
North Korea's winters are cold and summers hot; seasonal extremes are common, so plan for warming and cooling gear.
Pyongyang, KP: daylight ranges roughly 9h in winter to 14h in summer; noticeable winter darkness but outdoor breaks and light therapy ease it.
North Korea's winters are cold, with hot, humid monsoon summers; seasonal swings demand constant adaptation for a family with young kids.
North Korea offers almost no local senior tech talent for startups; leadership would have to be remote or from abroad, with significant barriers.
In North Korea, sex education is tightly controlled; open discussion is rare and resources for sexual health are scarce.
In North Korea (KP), social policies are tightly controlled with limited welfare. Civil liberties are restricted, affecting education, healthcare, and mobility.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: North Korea housing for a 2k sq ft family rental is scarce; foreign families often rely on corporate housing or extreme budgets to secure space.
Spring in North Korea can be pleasant much of the time, but expect cool mornings, possible rain, and occasional dust storms requiring layers.
Stability in North Korea remains fragile; sanctions, regime control, and regional tensions drive ongoing volatility that complicates planning.
In North Korea (KP), Juche remains totalizing and suppresses dissent. This clashes with our pluralistic, rights-focused family values.
North Korea's economy is dominated by the state. Formal capitalism is scarce, with limited markets and heavy security oversight.
Pyongyang has virtually no private game/animation studios; near-zero local production options for studios in North Korea.
North Korea summers are hot and humid with monsoon rains. Frequent outages and high humidity limit outdoor time.

In North Korea (KP), there are effectively no tax incentives or grants for games/interactive media; policy is restrictive.
In North Korea (KP), visa processes are notoriously opaque and costly for first-time US applicants. This risks long waits and high fees.
North Korea (KP) exhibits near-total regime control; trust is manufactured, not earned. For a family seeking democratic norms, genuine trust is effectively absent.
North Korea (KP) corruption is systemic and coercive, with security forces and officials shaping daily life through opaque controls.

North Korea (KP) has virtually no English-capable VFX artists. Expect Korean-language pipelines with translation/onboarding support.

North Korea's state media portray South Korea and others as threats. This clashes with our aim for regional openness and practical cross-border ties.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: North Korea (KP) is viewed with suspicion by neighbors and sanctions, keeping cross-border ties strained across East Asia.
In North Korea (KP), long-term family visas are unavailable; only highly restricted, escorted short visits via official channels.
In North Korea (Pyongyang), sidewalks are inconsistent and crossings can be challenging. Streets are car-dominated, so walking remains stressful.
In KP, Americans are rarely admitted and face heavy surveillance. We'd be treated as outsiders, not neighbors.
North Korea's state messaging and strict daily life offer rare, study-worthy contrasts; curiosity is hampered by propaganda and travel/internet limits.
Winters in North Korea bring frequent subzero days with cold winds; plan robust heating and emergency supplies.
KP context: target 37-38h weeks with occasional crunch and compensatory leave; remote/hybrid options fit Trey and Sarah's family-friendly goals.
In North Korea, state work demands dwarf family time; evenings and weekends are rarely protected, hurting Sarah's balance.
North Korea (KP): state-controlled labor with no unions and reports of forced labor; worker protections are minimal.
